title: Coronavirus: Covaxin approved for emergency use by WHO
content:
Bharat Biotech on Wednesday received the World Health Organization‚Äôs emergency use listing for its coronavirus vaccine, Covaxin.The decision was taken by a technical advisory group of the global health body that met earlier in the day. Emergency use listing is a procedure by the global health body to approve vaccines and other products for use during public health emergencies. The duration of the emergency use listing process depends on the quality of the data submitted by the vaccine manufacturer.üÜï WHO has granted emergency use listing (EUL) to #COVAXIN¬Æ (developed by Bharat Biotech), adding to a growing portfolio of vaccines validated by WHO for the prevention of #COVID19. pic.twitter.com/dp2A1knGtT‚Äî World Health Organization (WHO) (@WHO) November 3, 2021

It took more than three months for Covaxin to get the WHO‚Äôs clearance. Prime Minister Narendra Modi had pushed for the vaccine‚Äôs approval at the G20 summit held earlier this month. Mariangela Simao, the WHO‚Äôs assistant director general to access to vaccines and pharmaceuticals, said at a press briefing that it took more than six months for some shots to get approved. Simao added that vaccine validation is a very structured process. ‚ÄúThe process starts with the manufacturer submitting data to WHO for emergency use listing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWHO does analysis, and submits data to an external technical advisory committee. This group was composed of experts from six different countries.‚Äù The WHO‚Äôs senior health advisor Dr Joachim Hombach said an interim recommendation would soon be issued for Covaxin. ‚ÄúWe looked at interim data, safety data and data that came out of its use in India,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is reasonable to assume that its effectiveness is higher. But the clinical trial didn‚Äôt have sufficient power in order to estimate efficacy against severe disease.‚Äù There is also limited data on the use of Covaxin on pregnant women, Hombach added. WHO has however recommended Covaxin use in pregnant women.The WHO has said that there are plans to conduct studies on pregnant women.The global health body also said that Covaxin was found to be 78% effective against the coronavirus in case of all severities. The WHO also advised a gap of 14 or more days between the two shots. It added that Covaxin was ‚Äúextremely suitable for low-and middle-income countries due to easy storage requirements‚Äù. Covaxin can be stored at a temperature between two to eight degree Celsius.#Covaxin was found to have 78% efficacy against #COVID19 of any severity, 14 or more days after the second dose, and is extremely suitable for low- and middle-income countries due to easy storage requirements.‚Äî World Health Organization (WHO) (@WHO) November 3, 2021

Meanwhile, Union Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya thanked the World Health Organization for the approval. ‚ÄúThis is a sign of a capable leadership,‚Äù Mandaviya wrote on Twitter. ‚ÄúThis is the story of [Prime Minister Narendra] Modi ji‚Äôs resolve. Without WHO‚Äôs approval, people vaccinated with Covaxin doses were facing difficulties in travelling to other countries. Many countries only allow people vaccinated by a vaccine approved by them or World Health Organization.However, some countries such as Australia, Oman, Greece, Mauritius and Philippines, among other countries had recently recognised the vaccine. Simao, the WHO official said, said that citizens of countries with low vaccination coverage should not face restrictions in travelling.On October 18, the World Health Organization had said that it cannot ‚Äúcut corners‚Äù in deciding to recommend Covaxin for an emergency use listing.The world body‚Äôs technical advisory group had on October 26 sought ‚Äúadditional clarifications‚Äù from Bharat Biotech to conduct a final risk-benefit assessment for the emergency use listing of the vaccine.Before Covaxin, the World Health Organization has approved six vaccines from Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson, AstraZeneca-Oxford, Moderna, Sinopharm, and Sinovac.The Drugs Controller General of India had granted approval for restricted emergency use to Covaxin in January. Covaxin and Oxford-AstraZeneca‚Äôs Covishield were the first Covid-19 vaccines to be approved in India.Covaxin shelf life extended to 12 monthsMeanwhile, Bharat Biotech announced on Wednesday that the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation has aprroved the extension of the shelf life of its coronavirus vaccine, Covaxin, for up to 12 months from the date of manufacture.‚ÄúThis approval of shelf life extension is based on the availability of additional stability data, which was submitted to CDSCO [Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation],‚Äù the company tweeted.Shelf life is the length of time from the data of manufacture till which a product is fit for use.The approved shelf life of Covaxin was six months earlier, reported the Hindustan Times.
